newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle bid $68, passed - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle bid $68, passed - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle early Tuesday were bid $68.00 per cwt and passed by owners pricing cattle at $69.00 to $70.00, feedlot sources said.
About 4,000 head sold late Monday at $68.00 in the Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma area, steady with light sales late last week but down $1 from earlier-week trade, sources said.
The light sales fueled sentiment that packers could be aggressive buyers of cattle again this week to ensure adequate live inventory to fill beef orders.
No Kansas sales were reported late Monday and light bids Tuesday at $68.00 were firmly rebuffed, sources there said.
Several feedlot sources in the Panhandle said the market seemed poised to trade again at $68.00, which would be $1.00 lower than the bulk of last week's sales.
"We've got a few pens that might go this morning at $68.00," a Panhandle-area feedyard manager said.

Fed cattle prices were seen weaker than most of last week's trade amid a soft tone to beef prices. Beef values rallied most of last week, but drifted lower on Friday and continued slightly lower on Monday.
Beef prices on Monday were quoted down $0.05 to $0.20 per cwt on 179 fabricated beef loads sold, USDA reported.
